p: The influenza polymerase is a complex formed of three proteins including one called PB2 ( Te Velthuis and Fodor, 2016). Avian-style polymerases work well in bird cells, but poorly in humans. This species-specific restriction is due to the amino acid at position 627 in the PB2 subunit, which is a glutamate in birds and a lysine in humans ( Almond, 1977; Subbarao et al., 1993). Changing this glutamate to lysine in an avian polymerase is sufficient to make it active in human cells, but the reasons for this were unclear.
